instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SCL: What is SMBUS_BATT_SCL? SMBUS_BATT_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SDA: What is SMBUS_BATT_SDA? SMBUS_BATT_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Hello! Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here with a strange symptom! It was not turning on. I found a shorted cap near J5250 area, cleaned the area and replaced the cap and the board tuned on. No corrosion at all nowhere over the board but the J5250 area. I replaced the battery with a new one because the original was swollen. Gave back the machine to the costumer. 10 days after he returned and the battery was not recognized anymore. Sent the battery to RMA and got a replacement. The replacement did not even work. Sent it back again to RMA and today I received the new one. I put it on the machine again and the machine started with the new battery. Thought the problem was solved. Glued the battery into the machine and assembled the computer again. When I tried to turn it on the machine did not recognize the battery again and the OS says to replace the battery immediately. If I remove the magsafe charger the machine dies immediately and does not charge the battery. Any ideas on where to start? It's very unlikely that I got 3 bad batteries with the same defect!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Try known good working battery; even old, just for test.
New chinese battery are crappy...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: I do not have one. This Macs rarely show up here and I do not have any battery of this model here. Anyway, this battery is supposed to be original, the system even recognizes it as being made by SIMPLO.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
I still recommend to test known good one.
You can risk to waste time for nothing.

Just in case, check SCL/SDA lines in diode mode.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is OK.
Run ASD too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: I would definitely test another KG battery if I had one, but I don't have it! Will verify those lines and post back here

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Few days ago I received <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (3330) which gets stuck when battery is fully charged 100%; new (chinese) battery.
It doesn't start from battery alone, nor charger + battery, when battery is 100%; need to remove the battery...
The machine works perfectly, no other issue.
I just tested an old (inflated) battery, and all good.
I posted to explained what weird problems can generate a crappy battery...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: I understand that, but as I told, I do not have access to another battery and this is the third one my supplier has sent me?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is reading fine. 10k precisely.

Diode mode readings(red probe on GND, black on line)

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.480
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 0.490

I measured those lines on pin 5 and 6 of J7050 respectively.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.480
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 0.490"
Too big difference there.
Usually less than 1%...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Measured again and now SCL is .480 and SDA is .478

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Post exact value between pins 17/18 and 27/28 for <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Resistance between 17/18 = 3 Ohms
Resistance between 27/28 = 21 Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Do you get 3V42 on battery only?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: No I don't... I got a new battery today(supplier sent a new one) but I'm afraid of putting it in and burn it again, like it happened to the other 3 batteries...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Try old battery.
If reports some charge, then turn off the machine, disconnect charger and check 3V42.
If no good, then verify R/<DIODE>D7005</DIODE>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: It reports 79%, not charging and the battery status on system is Replace Now. If I unplug charger the machine dies immediately. 3.3V is present with charger, when I disconnect charger the machine dies and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> goes to 0V. I plugged in the last battery this computer burned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing too (on battery only), then check <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: No offense but this sounds 100% like a fucked battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 49235"]No offense but this sounds 100% like a fucked battery[/QUOTE]

That's exactly the problem... I tried 3 batteries... All of them work for some minutes then die... It's very unlikely that I got 3 fucked batteries... I think this machine has some kind of intermittent short that's killing the batteries... Besides, I do not buy cheap batteries... I always buy the best batteries I can to avoid problems, and this supplier alway sells me good batteries, just this machine is giving me headache!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 49234"]If <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing too (on battery only), then check <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> scales up until it reaches around 1.5V on battery, measures 12.56V on charger. <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> measures 9.98k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Check all the traces for battery connector.
Still looks like bad battery...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: All traces look good... Don't know what to do anymore... I think I will wait for another machine of the same kind arrive here and test the new battery on another computer to see if it burns the battery too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: I measured voltage on burned battery and it measures 12.2V, the same voltage measured on new battery the seller sent me. This is measured not on the connector itself but on the contacts on the battery controller board. Directly on the connector both batteries measure 2.33V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Battery is not enabled "on air".
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> should be pulled-down, through <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.
Post exact voltages for <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>, only battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>:

Pin1 = 1.675V
Pin2 = 1,675V
Pin3 = 1,6767V
Pin4 = 0,598V
Pin5 = 1,677V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message:
Crappy battery, or not good contact for <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> line.
Also possible battery processor got blocked for some reason.
I'm sure elements are good, as you have good voltage on them.
But internal processor settled up an error flag, because of short, or overcurrent detected.
In few words only, bad cheap chinese battery...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Not so cheap LOL! It was expensive actually... Should I try the new one then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Burning Batteries
threads.message: Well, in the end, as ALWAYS, you were ABSOLUTELY right! I got bad luck and got 3 consecutive bad batteries. The last one the seller sent me is working like a charm now! Thanks for all the help. Mod can close the topic!
